question: 工作
sourceMnemonic:
What is the "<kanji>industry</kanji> of <kanji>make</kanji>"? Well, it's when you industriously make things, obviously. That can only be <vocabulary>handicraft</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>crafts</vocabulary>, often referring to craft activities or hands-on projects done in elementary or middle school!

But wait, <ja>工作</ja> isn't just about glue and popsicle sticks! It can also mean <vocabulary>maneuvering</vocabulary>, in the sense of pulling strings behind the scenes. So, whether you're crafting a masterpiece or scheming a clever plan, <ja>工作</ja> encompasses the wonders of crafting!
sourceReadingMnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since <ja>作</ja> has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Your favorite <vocabulary>handicraft</vocabulary> is making <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja> <reading>sack</reading>s (<ja>こうさく</ja>). They're sacks that look exactly like <ja>こういち</ja>, and you're incredibly good at making them. Soon, the Tofugu offices will be decorated all over with your <ja>こういち</ja> sacks.
